Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Validating an Innovative Technology Classroom Observation Protocol (IT-COP) in High School Science Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Integration of technology aligned with authentic science applications can help teachers address the focus on real-world science and engineering practices in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) while also engaging students and enhancing their learning. However, few existing science classroom observation protocols examine the impact of this 'innovative' technology use in the classroom, and none measure the quality of technology implementation and its alignment with performance measures from the NGSS. Building on previous NSF-supported research, this study will develop the Innovative Technology Classroom Observation Protocol (IT-COP) to measure the impact of innovative technology integration on high school science teaching.

Co-led by an experienced team at Education Development Center and University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, this study consists of designing and validating the IT-COP and creating a companion mobile app for data collection along with an online How-To Guide to support its use by other researchers and evaluators. The framework of the IT-COP centers on technology types (STEM workplace technologies not common in the classroom; ubiquitous technologies that are common in the classroom and beyond, and instructional classroom technologies); alignment with science, engineering and mathematical practices, pedagogical practices relevant to these standards; and authentic STEM contexts. The IT-COP will be piloted in classrooms that serve underrepresented students with a wide range of access to technology tools. This research and resulting tool will provide the foundation for future work on complementary measures of student learning aligned with high-quality integration of technology and may serve as a teacher professional development resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With more and more educational resources invested in technology, researchers, evaluators and practitioners need tools to distinguish between applications of technology that support, enhance and even transform classroom instruction from those that are ineffective or even deleterious. The TOP-Science project addressed that need by piloting and validating a classroom observation protocol that captures the quality of technology use to support science inquiry in high school science classrooms. Building from the Classroom Technology Implementation Framework, which we developed under NSF Grant DRL-0833524 and published in 2015 (Parker, Stylinski, Bonney, Schillaci, & McAuliffe, 2015), we developed and piloted the Technology Observation Protocol for Science (TOP-Science) focused on the integration of technology into the key dimensions of our theoretical framework: science and engineering practices as operationalized in the Next Generation Science Standards; student-centered teaching that includes personalized instruction, autonomy, and competency-based learning; and relevant and authentic learning through contextualization.

Results

TOP-Science was developed over the course of four rounds of iterative pilot testing. Eight observers conducted 68 observations in 26 high school science classrooms across seven states. The final protocol includes four elements: 1) pre-observation teacher questions to understand teachers’ intentions for technology integration in their classes; 2) observation sheets where codes and field notes are recorded for the main framework dimensions (science and engineering practices, student-centered teaching, and contextualization) at 10-minute intervals; 3) post-observation teacher questions to gather the teachers’ reflections on their lessons; and 4) a code summary sheet that produces a multi-dimensional measure of technology integration quality. A detailed Reference Guide walks the observer through each step in the protocol process.

The protocol’s development addressed content validity through its alignment with an existing published theoretical framework, a review of literature, and a comparison of the protocol with similar protocols. During the piloting, we established content and face validity through an expert panel who reviewed three different drafts of the protocol and supporting materials. Satisfactory interrater reliability coefficients (Krippendorf’s alpha) were also calculated for the major categories of our protocol.

Intellectual Merit

Four key features emerged from the protocol development process: 1) focus on integration of technology; 2) use of a three-level coding system coupled with descriptive text; 3) focus on teacher intentions, actions, and reflections; and 4) synthesis of data into a quality measure. The coding system classifies and describes the degree of technology integration with the three theoretical framework dimensions: science and engineering practices, student-centered teaching, and contextualization.

TOP-Science’s focus on integration of technology in three key dimensions expands previous protocols’ measurement of quality technology use in classrooms in two ways: first by doing more than just registering the mere use of technology, and second by aligning technology use with key dimensions of classroom quality. Its use of a limited number of descriptors, a straightforward three-level coding system and the integration of descriptive text justifying each code choice provides a manageable frame for each 10-minute observation period clearly focused on the protocol’s purpose without attempting to observe all aspects of teaching and learning. Similarly, the focus on teacher intentions, actions, and reflections means that observers do not have to interpret student actions. Finally, the data-synthesizing tool allows observers to obtain a quality measure that can be used in analysis or professional development.

Broader Impacts

The work described here fills an important gap in existing protocols by providing a tool to capture the impact of technology use in the context of science classrooms with a focus on science inquiry and authentic investigations. It extends beyond simply noting the presence or absence of particular instructional features, and allows richer descriptions of technology integration with science practices, student-centered teaching, and contextualization. It offers a comprehensive view with consideration of teachers’ pre-class intentions and post-class reflections, and balances coding with written descriptions of evidence. The protocol’s demonstrated content and face validity, as well as the acceptable reliability estimates, demonstrate that it is a robust tool that provides a multi-dimensional measure of quality technology integration. The protocol was piloted across seven states in both low-resource and high-resource schools. Beyond its usefulness in researching the quality of technology integration, expert reviewers and external observers have highlighted TOP-Science’s potential value for teachers’ self-reflective evaluation of technology use in the context of science inquiry.

 

Parker, C. E., Stylinski, C., Bonney, C., Schillaci, R., & McAuliffe, C. (2015). Examining the quality of technology implementation in stem classrooms: Demonstration of an evaluative framework. Journal of Research on Technology in Education, 47(2), 105-121.
